./.title: HTML
./.body:
Coding & Cocktails Session 1:
Introduction to HTML

Overview
Tonight we covered HTML basics and best practices. Weâ€™ll put those to use here creating our own web page and begin understanding HTML structure as well as becoming more comfortable using HTML.
Reference the HTML Cheat Sheet at the end of the worksheet for a quick reminder on HTML element options as needed.

project.html.title: Part 1: HTML Page Structure
project.html.body:
Project
HTML provides your website with the underlying structure.  We'll start with a basic HTML structure and continue with adding page content.

If you are borrowing a laptop from us and using Cloud 9, please skip to the Cloud 9 section below!

Part 1: HTML Page Structure
We'll explore using the Emmet plugin in the Atom text editor that we use as our development environment.  This plugin helps us write our code faster and more efficiently.

In the CodingAndCocktails folder you created during the tools setup create a folder called html.
Open Atom.
Go to the File menu and choose Add project folder.
Navigate to and select the CodingAndCocktails\html folder.
On the left side of your screen, right click on the html folder and select New file.
Name the file index.html and press enter to save it in your CodingAndCocktails\html folder.
In the project pane on the left, double click on the index.html file to open it.
In your index.html file type html:5 and press the tab button on your keyboard.  This is some of the magic emmet can help us with and should come out looking like the following: 



   
   
   
   Document






See how the meta and title tags are indented since they are children of the head tag?
Setting up the HTML structure with emmet this way only works when the file you're developing in is already saved with the .html file extension. 

Cheers! You just set up the structural foundation of a web page!

Cloud9 Instructions

Sign up for an account at c9.io
Note: It will ask you for credit card information but you will not get charged for anything since we do not use features of Cloud9 that cost money.

Confirm your account from your email and log in to Cloud9.

Select Workspaces from the left side panel if you are not already there.

Choose Create a new workspace.

Pick a name for your workspace and enter it - it can be anything you'd like.  You do not need a description but feel free to add one if you'd like.

Leave your workspace as a "Public workspace".

In the template section choose HTML5

Click on the Create Workspace button`
Cloud9 will take a minute and create your workspace here`

Close the README.md file that is open when you get to your workspace.

From the File menu choose `New File``

From the File menu choose Save As... and use the file name index.html.  It should default to the workspace folder and display / in the Folder text box at the bottom, leave that as-is.

Click the green Save button

In the top menu bar choose Preview and then select Live Preview File (index.html)
This opens up a "browser" window that will show changes you make to your web page as you add content.  

    IMPORTANT! Any time the worksheet references viewing in Google     Chrome or refreshing the page in Google Chrome you will use this Preview area instead.
    

Continue with step 8 above. Luckily Cloud9 also lets us use the magic of emmet.

    Cloud9's initial page structure will be missing two of the above mentioned meta tags.  This is okay - you can ignore it and continue on with the worksheet.

part_2_head_section.html.title: Part 2: Head Section
part_2_head_section.html.body:
Part 2: Head Section
The head section contains data telling your browser more information about your page.  As we get farther into the year we'll discover more pieces of information that fit well here but tonight we'll just cover a couple.

In Atom, change the text in between the  tags.  This sets what will show on the browser tab.  Tonight we'll make a Cocktail Lounge site so set the text to "YourName's Cocktail Lounge"

Save the file.

In Google Chrome, choose Open File from the File menu.  Navigate to your CodingAndCocktails\html folder and open the index.html file.

You won't see anything exciting on the page yet, but you should see your title displayed in the page tab.

The remainder of our work will be done inside the  tags.  This is where any page content you can see goes.


Documentation
Mozilla Developer Network Head element documentation

part_3_body_section_headers.html.title: Part 3: Headers & Page Sections
part_3_body_section_headers.html.body:
Part 3: Headers & Page Sections
The body section of your HTML contains the visible part of your webpage.  Let's start building out some content!

We'll create sections within our page with div tags.  

In Atom, between the opening and closing  tags, type div.container and press the tab key.  This will create a div element with a class attribute with the value of container and will be the main container element for our page.

    Anytime you want to add a `class` attribute to an element you can add that by adding a period and then the classname you want to add when you're using emmet to create your elements. 

    An `id` attribute can be added by typing a `#` and then the name of the id you'd like to set.
    

    Want to know the difference between an id and a class?  Check out http://bit.ly/CnCIDvsClass
    
Your body section should now look like this: 

     



Nested inside the div.container create another div element with the class row. Type div.row and press the tab key. Don't forget to indent so your code is easy to read!
Your body section should now look like this: 

     
         
     



    Classes are often used to apply styling to elements - we will learn about styling next month. We'll see this in action later in the worksheet.  For now, don't worry too much about what the classes mean - we're focusing on the HTML this month.
    

Save the page, switch over to Google Chrome and reload.  Even though we've started adding content to the body section there is still nothing to see.

    If the file has not been saved you'll notice a small blue dot on the right side of the file's tab.  That goes away when the file has been saved.  The active tab has a blue line to the left so in the image below index.html is the selected tab and changes have not been saved.
    




Create an h1 tag inside the last div element. Type h1 then press the tab key. Write the name of your cocktail lounge between the opening and closing tags.

Save your file and reload it in Google Chrome. We have content!
 

After the closing h1 tag, add an h2 tag for a subtitle containing the text "Cocktails with a side of code." 
 It should look something like this: 
 
     
         
             Coding's Cocktail Lounge
             Cocktails with a side of code
         
     
 


Next, we'll want an "About" section, a "Menu" section, and a "Contact" section using more div tags. We'll need to add id attributes to these divs for navigation later in the worksheet.

Inside the div.container element but below closing  tag for the first div.row element, type div.row#about and press the tab key.  This will be the area for our "About" section. The element you created should look like this:


If you place your cursor on any HTML element, Atom will underline the matching opening or closing tag for you. 

Inside that about div, we'll title the section.  Since this is the third most important heading on the page we'll use an h3 tag. Place the text "About" between the tags.



Repeat this process twice more for the Menu and Contact sections.

In between the opening and closing tags for the div.container element but below the closing  tag for the about section, type div.row#menu and press the tab key. This will be the area for our "Menu" section.

Inside the menu div, title the section with the text "Menu" using an h3 tag.

In between the opening and closing tags for the div.container, below the menu section, add a row with the id of "contact."  row. 

Create an h3 tag with the text "Contact" between the opening and closing div tags created in the last step.



Save your file and reload it in Google Chrome. Your page should look similar to this:



Documentation
If you want to read up on header or div elements check out the documentation from Mozilla Developer Network:
MDN Documentation on heading elements
MDN Documentation on div elements

part_4_body_section_-_paragraphs.html.title: Part 4: Paragraphs
part_4_body_section_-_paragraphs.html.body:
Part 4: Paragraphs
Most websites have some text on the page. Let's add some to ours!

In Atom, after the first h3 tag, add a paragraph tag (Hint: That's just a p tag!) Don't forget to use emmet so you don't have to write out all the , > and /.

You can either write your own text or try using lorem ipsum text. 
Lorem ipsum text is often used as dummy text in the printing industry to show what the page layout will look like when you may not know what your content is yet. The lorem ipsum text is derived from a work that dates back to 45 BC!

To add your own text just type it in between your p tags.

If you want to use lorem ipsum text for now we'll use emmet to help us quickly add this.   Type lorem inside the p tags and push tab.  This will insert some placeholder lorem ipsum text for you. It should look like this: 

If you know exactly how many words you want you can specify that with a number after the `lorem` word in your code.  For example if I wanted 50 words I would type `lorem50` and then push `tab`.  



Save your html file and refresh in your Google Chrome browser. You should now see something like this: 



Documentation
Mozilla Developer Network paragraph element documentation

part-5-inspecting-the-page.html.title: Part 5: Inspecting the Page
part-5-inspecting-the-page.html.body:
Part 5: Inspecting the Page
You'll often find yourself needing to look at how your page is being rendered in the browser to troubleshoot issues so let's give that a try.

In Google Chrome, right-click on your h2 text and choose Inspect
 This will open up your Chrome Developer Tools to the elements tab

Notice you can see all of your tags that you've added to the page and how they are nested inside each other. It should look something like this:


Notice as you mouse over elements in the Dev Tools that they are highlighted in the rendered view above.


You can also click the arrows to the left of your div elements to expand them and see the elements inside them.

In addition, you can make and preview changes here before making them in your code.

In the elements section of the Dev Tools, double click on the text inside your h2 tag. This should make it editable. Change it to "Hello World" and then press enter 


Your h2 text should now display "Hello World" on your rendered page.

This only lasts until you refresh the page! If you want to make a lasting change you need to make the change to your code. 

Refresh your page to see your text return to what you have in your code.



You can either keep your Dev Tools open or close them with the small x in the upper right corner of the Dev Tools

Another quick way to open the tools at any time is through a keyboard short cut:






Windows Key Combination
Mac Key Combination




ctrl + shift + i
cmd + option + i



Element inspection comes in very handy when you're trying to style your page too so we'll use this a lot next month when we learn about CSS!

part_5_body_section_-_images.html.title: Part 6: Images
part_5_body_section_-_images.html.body:
Part 6: Images
Add an image to your about section to bring some interest to your page.

In Google Chrome, navigate to flickr.com

Search for a cocktail image

Change the license filter from "Any License" to "Commercial use allowed"

Choose your favorite image, click on it and click on the download icon in the lower right corner.  You get to choose what size you'd like on your page. You'll want to save it into your CodingAndCocktails\html folder.  Name it something easy to remember.
 

In Atom, add an img tag just below the "About" header on your page.Don't forget to use emmet to complete your tag for you - it will automatically add your `src` and `alt` attributes for you but you still have to fill out their content!  The `src` attribute tells your code where to look for your image and the `alt` attribute content gets displayed if your image is not able to be rendered and is used by screen readers for better accessibility. 

For your src attribute you'll need to point to where the file is.  Since we placed our image in the same folder we only need to provide the file name you chose in step 4 (including the file extension!) inside the quotation marks here.

Save your file and reload it in Google Chrome.


Documentation
Mozilla Developer Network image element documentation

part_6_body_section_-_tables.html.title: Part 7: Tables
part_6_body_section_-_tables.html.body:
Part 7: Tables
Add some content to the menu section using an HTML table. 

In Atom, add an HTML table under the "Menu" header. 
Don't forget to use emmet to help you write your HTML faster!

Check out the MDN documentation on HTML tables to figure out how to structure your table. There are samples near the bottom of the page.
The "Simple table with header" is a good example to follow.
All of the table attributes listed in the documentation are now "deprecated" - meaning they are no longer used in HTML but are handled in a different way (usually through CSS which we will cover in a future class). You can scroll past the attributes to get to the exmaples.

One column should contain the Menu Item and the other column should contain Price.



Add a class attribute to your table element with a value of "table".

Save your file and reload it in Google Chrome.

Your table should end up looking something like this but feel free to include your own drinks and prices!





Documentation
Mozilla Developer Network table element documentation

part_7_body_section_-_forms.html.title: Part 8: Forms
part_7_body_section_-_forms.html.body:
Part 8: Forms
Under the "Contact" header add a form to allow users to contact you. Forms typically require a bit of JavaScript but that tool is not in our toolbelt just yet we'll use a tool called Formspree. You can read up on it at formspree.io.

In Atom, under the "Contact" header add a  element to your page.

Set the action attribute's value to https://formspree.io/youremail@example.com replacing the youremail@example.com text with your actual email address.

Add a method attribute to your form element with a value of "POST". This is required to make the form work with Formspree.
Remember attribute values are surrounded by double quotation marks! 

The form will have sections for a name, an email address and a message along with a Submit button.

Inside the form element type div.form-group*4 and push the tab key to add the four form sections.
You asked emmet to create a div element (`div`) with the class form-group (`.form-group`), four of them (`*4`)


The first section is the name section. In between the first opening and closing div.form-group tags, add a label element. Type label  and push the tab key

Set the label's for attribute value to "nameInput"

Add the text "Name" in between the opening and closing label tags.

Just below the label element type input#nameInput.form-control then press the tab key to create your input element with the id "nameInput" and class form-control.
Remember, ids are created by using a `#` followed by the id name you want to add and classes are created by using a `.` followed by the class name you want to add

Add a name attribute to that input element and set it's value to "name"
Emmet will automatically add your `type` attribute and leaving it with the value "text" for our first input is perfect!

Also add a placeholder attribute and set the value to "First and Last Name". 
Your code should look similar to this now:

 Name
 





Save your file and reload it in Google Chrome.  The form is starting to come together!  It should look like this:
 

The second section will be for the user email address. In between the opening and closing tags for the second form-group div, add a label element. 

Set the for attribute to "emailInput" 

In between the opening and closing tags set the text to "Email Address".

Below the label element, add an input element with an id of "emailInput" but this time set the type attribute to "email"

On the input element, add a name attribute with a value of "_replyto".  This is another requirement to make the form work with Formspree.

Add a class attribute of "form-control".

Add a placeholder attribute with a value of "Email Address"



Save your file and reload it in Google Chrome. Progress! It should look like this:
 

Create the area for the message. Inside the third form-group add a label element.

Set the label element's for attribute to "messageInput" 

Add text "Message" in between the opening and closing label tags.

Below the label, add a textarea element with a class of "form-control".

Set the name attribute of the textarea element to "message"

Set the id attribute to "messageInput" 

Leave the cols and rows attributes at the default values provided.

Add a placeholder attribute with a value of "Message Text".
Why are we using a textarea element instead of an input element here?
    Look at the MDN documentation for input linked at the bottom of the page. Scroll down to the `type` attribute and look at the explanation for the value of "text".  This shows it only allows a single line of text to be entered when the input elements `type` attribute is set to "text".  Since a message is usually multiple lines, a `textarea` element is a better choice for the message.



Save your file and reload it in Google Chrome. It should look like this: 


In between the the final form-group div opening and closing tags, add an input element with a type value of "submit".

Add two classes: btn and btn-default.

Add a value attribute with a value of "Send". 


Type `input.btn.btn-default` and then press the`tab` key to add both classes to the input element at the same time
The `value` attribute sets the text of the submit button so feel free to set the text to whatever you'd like!

Save your file and reload it in Google Chrome. The final form should look like this: 
    


Since our websites are not deployed to a server, the form won't actually work right now. 

If you'd like to try putting your site up on the internet ask a mentor to help you push it up to GitHub Pages and then you can test out your form.  The way Formspree works is that you'll have to test it once, which will send you an email asking you to confirm your email address and from then on, your form will be functioning!
Documentation
Mozilla Developer Network form element documentation
Mozilla Developer Network input element documentation
Mozilla Developer Network textarea element documentation

part_8_body_section_-_navigation_&_foote.title: Part 9: Navigation & Footer
part_8_body_section_-_navigation_&_foote.body:
Part 9: Navigation & Footer
Most websites have a way to navigate around.  HTML 5 added nav and footer elements to the mix so let's practice using those!

In Atom, create a navigation row section and add the navbar.

Above the first div.row (now displayed in your code as a div element with the row class - ) add a new div.row.


In between the opening and closing div tags just created, add a nav element with the classes navbar and navbar-default inside the div from step ii.

Save your file and reload it in Google Chrome.
Nothing to see here. How does a user move around? We'll add the navigation links in Part 11: Anchors!



Create a footer row section and add a footer.  

Add another div.row just inside the  tag that is closing the  element.

Add a footer element in between the opening and closing tags of that div.row.

Footers often contain copyright information so try using an HTML entity to add a copyright symbol. In between the opening and closing  tags add the text © and the text " Copyright your name 2017"



Save your file and reload it in Google Chrome.


Documentation
Mozilla Developer Network nav element documentation
Mozilla Developer Network footer element documentation

part-10-lists.html.title: Part 10: Lists
part-10-lists.html.body:
Part 10: Lists
Lists often come in handy on a webpage - both ordered (numbered) lists and unordered (bulleted) lists.  Website navigation is often an unordered list of links so that's where we'll be using a list. We have three page sections - About, Menu, and Contact - so we'll need three navigation list items.

In Atom, use the magic of emmet to make your life easier.  In between the opening and closing nav tags, type ul.nav.navbar-nav>li*3 and push the tab key.  Voila! An unordered list with two classes and three list items ready to go!
You told emmet that you wanted an unordered list (`ul`) with a `.nav` class and a `.navbar-nav` class with child (`>`) list item elements (`li`), three of them (`*3`) 

In between each list item's opening and closing tags type the section names About, Menu and Contact.

Save your file and reload it in Google Chrome.


Navigation items display on the page but don't yet navigate anywhere - add that in Part 11.
Documentation
Mozilla Developer Network unordered list element documentation
Mozilla Developer Network list item element documentation
Mozilla Developer Network ordered list element documentation

part_8_body_section_-_anchors_aka_links..title: Part 11: Anchors (aka Links)
part_8_body_section_-_anchors_aka_links..body:
Part 11: Anchors (aka Links)
The navigation items should take the user to the page sections they reference. In order to do that, anchor elements need to be added to create a hyperlink to those sections of the page.

In Atom, select the "About" text in the first list item and use the keyboard shortcut below to wrap a tag around other content.




Windows Key Combination
Mac Key Combination




ctrl + alt + w
ctrl + w




Type just an a in the prompt that comes up and press enter. An anchor tag with an href attribute will show up wrapped around your "About" text. The "About" text should now look like this: 
 About


The href attribute tells the anchor where to go when it is clicked.  Clicking "About" should move to the "About" section of the page.  The about section is the div element with the id about.  Set the anchor tag's href value to "#about".

Repeat this process for the Menu and Contact sections.  

Save your file and reload it in Google Chrome.


We now have a working navigation section!
Since we don't have a lot of content on our page it may not appear to work at first.  If you shrink the size of your browser window down so it is about half as tall, try clicking on the menu navigation item again and the menu section should show at the top!
Documentation
Mozilla Developer Network anchor element documentation

bonus-styling.html.title: Bonus: Styling
bonus-styling.html.body:
Bonus: Styling

In the head section of your index.html file add this tag just above the closing  tag:


Save your file, go to Google Chrome and reload.



We utilized a styling framework called Bootstrap to help us do some quick styling today and tied it to our html with the link tag in our head section.  
Click here to sign up for next month if you want to learn more about styling and how it works!

html-cheat-sheet.html.title: HTML Cheat Sheet
html-cheat-sheet.html.body:
HTML Cheat Sheet
A handy reference for HTML elements with a short description of the element.
https://websitesetup.org/HTML5-cheat-sheet.pdf

answer-key.html.title: Answer Key
answer-key.html.body:
Answer Key
View the code answer key in our GitHub repository here: https://github.com/KansasCityWomeninTechnology/AnswerKeys/blob/master/html/index.html

homework.html.title: Homework
homework.html.body:
Homework
In order to continue building our coding skills, we need to practice - just like when playing sports or learning a musical instrument.

troubleshooting.html.title: Troubleshooting
troubleshooting.html.body:
Troubleshooting
Troubleshooting Exercises
Try some troubleshooting so you can feel more confident coding on your own!

Open a new file in Atom and save it in your CodingAndCocktials/html folder as troubleshooting.html

Paste the following code into the file



    
    Coding & Cocktails Troubleshooting
    


    Exercise 1
    Figure out what is wrong with this HTML.

    Does anyone know why there is no image displayed below this paragraph?

    
    

    
    How does my table look?
    
        
            Winter Sport
            Equipment
        
        
            Skiing
            Skis
            Poles
            Gloves
            Boots
            Hot Chocolate
            Snow
        
        
            Snowboarding
            Snowboard, boots, gloves, etc.
        
        Snowshoing
        Snowshoes
        
            Sledding
            Sled, etc.
        
    

    
    Is this list formatted according to best practices?
    Here is a list:
    1. First item 
    2. Second item 
    3. Third item 

    
    Keep an eye to the best practices in this section.
    Yay for pretty colors!!!

    This is another paragraph. There is a Coding & Cocktails link in this paragraph. I want only this sentence to be bold. Which cocktail is your favorite tonight?  What is your favorite holiday tradition?  Who likes snow & ice?  Is 3 This sentence should be in italics

    
    

  



Save the file and open it in your Google Chrome browser.

The first thing to fix is that our image is not displayed underneath the first paragraph.  See if you can make the image show up by editing the HTML. 
Remember to save and refresh the page in Google Chrome to see your changes

The second issue to fix is the table. It should have two columns (Sport and Equipent) with several rows of data.

Update the list of items to use an HTML ordered list so our webpage has the correct structure.

Update the HTML headers keeping an eye to our HTML best practices.

The img tag is missing an important attribute. Update the image tag to have this attribute.


View Pages and Answer Key
View Starting Point: http://kansascitywomenintechnology.github.io/examples/html-troubleshooting/exercise1.html
View Solution:
http://kansascitywomenintechnology.github.io/examples/html-troubleshooting/solutions/exercise1.html
Code Answer Key:
https://github.com/KansasCityWomeninTechnology/examples/blob/master/html-troubleshooting/solutions/exercise1.html

homework-bonus.html.title: Bonus
homework-bonus.html.body:
Homework: Bonus
This exercise only requires one addition.  Can you figure out what it is? 

Open a new file in Atom and save it in your CodingAndCocktials/html folder as troubleshooting2.html

Paste the following code into the file


    
    Coding & Cocktails Troubleshooting


    This is my Bonus Exercise
    It looks like everything is working ok.
    But there is  one thing missing.Can you figure out what it is?




Take a close look at the page structure and see if you can figure out what is missing.


View Pages and Answer Key
View Starting Point: http://kansascitywomenintechnology.github.io/examples/html-troubleshooting/bonus.html
View Solution:
http://kansascitywomenintechnology.github.io/examples/html-troubleshooting/solutions/bonus.html
Code Answer Key:
https://github.com/KansasCityWomeninTechnology/examples/blob/master/html-troubleshooting/solutions/bonus.html
